prop.head.label.name: Part
prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Factors in Deciding Whether Transfer Is Appropriate

head.headtext: Factors militating against transfer—Ability to manage cases without transfer

para.paratext: The Panel has not readily accepted arguments that transfer is unnecessary because the parties can and will voluntarily permit coordination of discovery and pretrial proceedings.[1] The Panel will consider these arguments, however, and if the parties can convince the Panel that transfer would serve no purpose, transfer may be denied.[2] Even where the Panel does not base a decision denying centralization on the sufficiency of voluntary cooperation, it frequently will encourage the parties to avail themselves of voluntary cooperation.[3]

The Panel as noted the difference in complexity between a group of cases where the parties are represented by the same counsel and a similar group of cases with many different attorneys representing the parties. This may be observed in connection with an order for centralization.[4] The Panel also cites the presence of common counsel as an indicator of lack of managerial complexity in orders denying transfer.[5]

The Panel has considered the role that trial of one case would have on the entire litigation and has declined to transfer cases where it appeared that discovery in multiple cases would not be necessary or likely if one case were tried.[6] This has been used by the Panel as one reason for denying transfer of certain patent cases because a decision in one of the related cases would be given collateral estoppel effect, obviating further litigation.[7] The Panel has similarly considered the potential res judicata effect of a decision in litigation involving the same parties.[8] Similarly, where the parties have common counsel and are cooperating in the litigation of the case, the Panel may be persuaded that voluntary cooperation is a viable alternative to transfer.[9]

The Panel's consideration of this factor is implicit in every decision made by it. If conventional case handling practices in the districts in which the actions are filed would be adequate for management of the litigation, it may be said that an alternative to transfer exists. More fundamentally, however, the requirement of the statute that transfer “advance the just and efficient conduct of the actions” would not be met.[10]

The Panel has considered the potential for the judges to whom the pending cases are assigned effecting appropriate coordination of pretrial proceedings.[11] This may be an adequate alternative to transfer, especially where few actions are involved or where the districts are in close proximity.[12] Centralization is unlikely where there are pending motions to approve settlements.[13]
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.

See, e.g., In re Computervision Corp. Securities Litigation, 814 F. Supp. 85 (J.P.M.L. 1993); In re General Tire & Rubber Co. Securities Litigation, 429 F. Supp. 1032, 1034 (J.P.M.L. 1977); In re Iowa Beef Packers, Inc., 309 F. Supp. 1259 (J.P.M.L. 1970). But see In re USS Trenton Disaster Litigation, 383 F. Supp. 1406, 1407 (J.P.M.L. 1974) (proposed stipulation for use of discovery in all actions one reason for denying transfer).

In re Auto Body Shop Antitrust Litigation, 37 F. Supp. 3d 1388 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2014) (voluntary coordination impracticable because of large number of parties and cases in 5 disctricts); In re: Natrol, Inc. Glucosamine/Chondroitin Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 26 F. Supp. 3d 1392 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2014) (Panel rejects argument that voluntary cooperation would be sufficient to manage litigation given expected complex discovery).

See, e.g., In re Gerber Probiotic Products Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 899 F. Supp. 2d 1378 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2012); In re: Navistar Maxxforce Engines Marketing, Sales Practices and Products Liability Litigation, 67 F. Supp. 3d 1382 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2014) (trial scheduled in 2 months; centralization would only delay resolution); In re: Hangtime, Inc., Telephone Consumer Protection Act (TCPA) Litigation, 52 F. Supp. 3d 1375 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2014); In re: National Ass'n for Advancement of Multijurisdiction Practice Litigation, 52 F. Supp. 3d 1377 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2014). For discussion by the Panel of the differences between transfer under section 1404(a) and section 14-7, see In re Cygnus Telecommunications Technology, LLC, Patent Litigation, 177 F. Supp. 2d 1375 (J.P.M.L. 2001).

See, e.g., In re Santa Fe Natural Tobacco Company Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 178 F. Supp. 3d 1377 (J.P.M.L. 2016) (Panel notes few common counsel in ordering transfer in docket comprising only 5 cases in 4 districts); In re Foot Locker, Inc., Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA) and Wage and Hour Litigation, 787 F. Supp. 2d 1364 (J. P.M.L. 2011) (transfer would not cause any prejudice to the parties because of common counsel).

See, e.g., In re Proton-Pump Inhibitor Products Liability Litigation (No. II), 261 F. Supp. 3d 1351 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2017) (increase in number of lawyers for parties favors centeralization where previously denied); In re Petrobras Securities Litigation, 222 F. Supp. 3d 1345 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2016); In re Uber Technologies, Inc., Wage and Hour Employment Practices, 158 F. Supp. 3d 1372 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2016); In re Global Tel*Link Corporation Inmate Calling Services Litigation, 140 F. Supp. 3d 1338 (J.P.M.L. 2015); In re: Financial Recovery Services, Inc., Fair Debt Collection Practices Act (FDCPA) Litigation, 122 F. Supp. 3d 1370 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2015); In re: SFPP, L.P., R.R. Property Rights Litigation, 121 F. Supp. 3d 1360 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2015); In re: SeaWorld Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 118 F. Supp. 3d 1373 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2015); In re: Caribbean Cruise Line, Inc., Telephone Consumer Protection Act (TCPA) Litigation, 89 F. Supp. 3d 1356 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2015); In re Townsend Farms Organic Anti-Oxidant Blend Products Liability Litigation, 24 F. Supp. 3d 1372 (J.P.M.L. 2014) (9 actions in 9 districts, Panel also notes high degree of agreement among counsel); In re Sempris Membership Program Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 999 F. Supp. 2d 1370 (J.P.M.L. 2014); In re Lloyds Bank PLC International Mortgage Service Loan Litigation, 997 F. Supp. 2d 1352 (J.P.M.L. 2014) (Panel notes common counsel for plaintiffs); In re Lipitor (Atorvastatin Calcium) Marketing, Sales Practices and Products Liability Litigation, F. Supp. 2d , 2013 WL 4048505 (J.P.M.L. 2013); In re Ocala Funding, LLC, Commercial Litigation, 867 F. Supp. 2d 1332 (J.P.M.L. 2012). Conversely, the absence of common counsel is sometimes an expressed reason favoring transfer. See, e.g., In re Mobile Telecommunications Technologies, LLC Patent Litigation, 222 F. Supp. 3d 1337 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2016) (only some common counsel); In re Johnson & Johnson Talcum Powder Products Marketing, Sales Practices and Products Liability Litigation, 220 F. Supp. 3d 1356 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2016) (voluntary cooperation not feasible given the lack of common counsel for the parties); In re Santa Fe Natural Tobacco Company Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 178 F. Supp. 3d 1377 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2016).

See, e.g., In re Bourns Patent Litigation, 385 F. Supp. 1260, 1261 (J.P.M.L. 1974); In re Shipley Co., Inc. Patent Litigation, 383 F. Supp. 847, 848 (J.P.M.L. 1974); In re Disposable Diaper Patent Validity Litigation, 362 F. Supp. 567 (J.P.M.L. 1973); In re Lehman Equipment Co. Patent Infringement Litigation, 360 F. Supp. 1402 (J.P.M.L. 1973).

See generally Blonder-Tongue Laboratories, Inc. v. University of Illinois Foundation, 402 U.S. 313, 91 S. Ct. 1434, 28 L. Ed. 2d 788 (1971). See also In re Dietgoal Innovations, LLC ('561) Patent Litigation, 999 F. Supp. 2d 1380 (J.P.M.L. 2014) (history of dismissals and fact Markman hearing already held in one action militates against transfer).
See In re Buffalo Valley Gas Authority Litigation, 429 F. Supp. 1029, 1032 (J.P.M.L. 1977).
See, e.g., In re Townsend Farms Organic Anti-Oxidant Blend Products Liability Litigation, 24 F. Supp. 3d 1372 (J.P.M.L. 2014).
See 28 U.S.C.A. § 1407(a). The statute is reprinted in § 3:19.

See, e.g., In re Crest Sensitivity Treatment & Protection Toothpaste Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 867 F. Supp. 2d 1348 (J.P.M.L. 2012) (discussing ways to manage discovery in multiple actions); In re Royal American Industries, Inc. Securities Litigation, 407 F. Supp. 242, 243 (J.P.M.L. 1976); In re Iowa Beef Packers, Inc., 309 F. Supp. 1259, 1260 (J.P.M.L. 1970).

See, e.g., In re Forcefield Energy, Inc. Securities and Derivative Litigation, 154 F. Supp. 3d 1351 (J.P.M.L. 2015); In re Seaworld Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation (No. II), 118 F. Supp. 3d 1373 (J.P.M.L. 2015) (two actions in adjacent districts in same state); In re Deer Consumer Products, Inc. Securities Litigation, 109 F. Supp. 3d 1372 (J.P.M.L. 2015) (two action in adjoining districts cited as reason voluntary cooperation would be preferable to centralization); In re Bratton Litigation, 206 F. Supp. 2d 1366 (J.P.M.L. 2002).

In re Building Products of Canada Corp. Organic Shingles Products Liability Litigation, 856 F. Supp. 2d 1345 (J.P.M.L. 2012); In re Telecommunications Providers' Fiber Optic Cable Installation Litigation (No. III), 802 F. Supp. 2d 1364 (J.P.M.L. 2011); In re Power Balance, LLC, Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 777 F. Supp. 2d 1345 (J.P.M.L. 2011) (proposed settlement pending); In re Toyota Motor Corp. Prius HID Headlamp Products Liability Litigation, 754 F. Supp. 2d 1380 (J.P.M.L. 2010).
